attributes.action: put maximum pressure on the Japanese government to abide by the moratorium on the slaughter of hump back whales
attributes.action_prefix: We the undersigned petition the Prime Minister to
attributes.background:
Living creatures deserve to be treated humanely and biodiversity is essential to the survival of our planet.
This edited article gives a quick oversight;
TOKYO (AFP) — Japan came under a storm of criticism Monday for going ahead with its largest whale hunt yet, with Australia's Labor Party calling for the military to be brought in. The hunt will include humpback whales for the first time.
Japan plans to kill 950 whales. Australia, Britain and New Zealand condemned the decision to go ahead with the catch. 
Humpback whales, protected under a 1966 moratorium are renowned for their complex songs and acrobatic displays.
Only Norway and Iceland openly defy a 1986 moratorium on commercial hunting of all whales. Japan argues that it abides by the agreement with its ‘scientific research’ but meat from the hunt goes on dinner plates.
Britain is considering making a "high-level diplomatic protest" to Japan, said a spokeswoman for the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs.
